results.title: A Toast to Melbourne
results.creator_credit: John Dixon, Kent Chadwick, Victorian Film Corporation and Cambridge Film Productions
results.brief_description: Using archival film, aerial photography, stills, prints and contemporary footage, this documentary presents the city of Melbourne and its lifestyle. Looks at the unique Victorian architecture that transformed Melbourne from a tent city during the Gold Rush to a modern and prosperous city. Captures the vibrant streetscapes, the trams, the elaborate arcades and some of the institutions that cater to Melbourne’s elite such as the Georges store and the Melbourne Club. Highlights the range of sporting activities available, showing John McEnroe, Dennis Lillee and Greg Norman among others. Visits the Separation Tree in the Botanical Gardens planted to commemorate Melbourne’s independence from NSW, the bustling Queen Victoria Market, the suburbs of St Kilda and Brighton, its beaches and the Arts Precinct. Shows crowded restaurants and pubs with rock band performances that contribute to Melbourne’s nightlife. Also includes footage of areas and buildings which have disappeared or undergone major transformations since this film was produced: the docklands; the city square; Swanston Street; Foster’s Brewery; ports. The following Australian identities are also shown: Barry Humphries, Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, Bob Hawke, Andrew Peacock, Phillip Adams, Dick Hamer, Joan Sutherland, Jon English, Derryn Hinch, Mike Brady, Lindsay Thompson and an assortment of VFL footballers.

results.title: The Right person for the job
results.brief_description: Excerpts from a seminar held on equal rights legislation held at Trinity College, Melbourne University, are interspersed with dramatisations of problems which women face in the workforce. Shows the role of the conciliation officer and the hearing of a discrimination case by the Equal Opportunity Board

results.title: Victoria's Energy
results.creator_credit: Dept of Minerals and Energy AV Workshop
results.brief_description: Energy is the lifeblood of an industrial society. The program looks at Victoria’s four primary energy sources- oil, coal, gas and solar energy-and discusses their futures

results.title: The Models
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, John Cruthers and Musical Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Pop Movie”.
Melbourne new wave band “The Models” are shown performing live at Bombay Rock and discussing their music, record contracts and attraction for playing in a rock band. Filmed on the eve of the release of their first album.

results.title: Home on the range: U.S. bases in Australia
results.creator_credit: Gil Scrine and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Examines the existence of U.S. military bases in Australia and how their presence has affected its position in the nuclear arms race between the Soviet Union and America. Considers the question of nuclear arms in Australia in terms of the presence of the C.I.A. in Australia, its manipulation on the course of Australia’s political affairs and the mounting opposition by the general public. Script: Gil Scrine, Bob Connolly, David Bradbury Narrated by Annie Webster, David Ritchie

results.title: The Work That Was. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Who Pays the Price? (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system. “Futures” (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, unemployment in country towns, and the prospects of the coming mineral boom.

results.title: Damn it. B.Y.O.
results.brief_description: 1. “Damn it” (Sweden, 1980, 20 min.): An animated film showing the physical and emotional stresses experienced by a young man in a big city. 2. “BYO” (Brisbane, 1980, 19 min.): A dramatisation of a school dance where smuggling alcohol causes more trouble than it’s worth.
